title: 111_hr5698
content: Protection of employees from retaliation by their employer for cooperating in investigations is prohibited under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990. This amendment includes a new section, SEC. 6003, that addresses retaliation. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 prohibits employers from retaliating against employees for reporting violations, refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct, providing information to Congress or relevant proceedings, or initiating legal action related to the Act. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 prohibits employer retaliation against employees involved in legal proceedings or actions related to the Act. Employees can bring discrimination claims under specific rules and procedures outlined in the Act. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 prohibits employer retaliation against employees involved in legal proceedings or actions related to the Act. The table of contents in the Act is amended by striking the item relating to section 6003 and inserting a new entry. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 prohibits employer retaliation against employees involved in legal proceedings related to the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act prohibit employer retaliation against employees involved in legal proceedings related to the Acts. This includes notifying authorities of violations, refusing to participate in noncompliant conduct, providing information for proceedings, and commencing legal actions. Employees protected under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act are safeguarded from employer retaliation if they engage in legal proceedings related to the Acts, such as commencing or participating in proceedings, testifying, or assisting in actions to uphold the Acts' purposes. If discrimination occurs, the employee can bring an action following specific legal procedures outlined in the Acts.
